en.value: natural disaster
Natural disasters can be very dangerous for humans.
tsunami
Tsunamis can be caused by earthquakes.
hurricane
Hurricane Katrina devastated the south of the United States in 2005.
earthquake
An earthquake of 7.8 on the Richter scale shook Indonesia.
flood
The floods that happened in China have caused many deaths.
drought
Drought is a big problem for Spain.
deforestation
Uncontrolled felling leads to deforestation.
climate change
Climate change can lead to strong natural disasters.
animals in danger of extinction
The panda is an animal in danger of extinction.
pollution
Using public transport can reduce pollution.
predator
The tiger is the dominant predator in the jungles of Bengal.
leopard
Leopards only hunt at night.
natural habitat
On a safari holiday, you can observe wild animals in their natural habitat.
lion
The lion is considered as the king of the jungle.
jungle
The jungle is home to a countless number of exotic species.
wildlife
Hunting has had a devastating impact on wildlife in the region.
wolf
Wolves are a species in danger of extinction.
elephant
The elephant has a very long trunk.
bear
A bear can weigh up to 500kg.
giraffe
The giraffe is the tallest animal of all.
Save the planet!
Discussing environmental problems - Future perfect continuous
Environ­mental problems
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Did you see that there's been another [k]tsunami[/k] in the Far East? Apparently, the waves were over twenty metres high!
Ah dear, that's terrible. Lots of people say that [k]global warming[/k] is causing these natural disasters.
How can warmer temperatures cause hurricanes and [k]earthquakes[/k]?
It has something to do with the changes in pressure caused by the melting [k]ice caps[/k].
This all seems rather far-fetched! I'm not sure the experts know what they're talking about!
I disagree. What's more, the main contributor to global warming is caused by the [k]pollution[/k] that we produce!
Well, if that is the case then our governments should be doing more to reduce it.
It's not just our governments' job. We also need to do more as individuals.
Christine
Thomas
Select the correct option.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Choose one of the photographs and explain the possible consequences that this natural disaster may have.

Deforestation is a big problem in areas like South America. Large areas of the rainforest are being destroyed. This means that lots of different species of animal are losing their habitat, so many species are in danger of extinction.
Wild animals
Did you enjoy your day out?
I suppose so, though I would have rather seen the animals in their [k]natural habitat[/k].
I guess it's not like at the safari parks. They keep the [k]lions[/k] and elephants in such small enclosures. It's sad.
I agree. Elephants naturally live in [k]herds[/k] and graze on the grasses of the savanna. Small spaces aren't right for them.
Was there anything you enjoyed about it?
Well, I liked how I could observe such a wide range of [k]wildlife[/k] in one place, but there was so much walking to do!
Did you see any [k]predators[/k] too?
Yes, there were lions and tigers.
Maria
John
Grammar: Future perfect continuous
The sentence looks backwards from a time in the future.
I've been working here for over 10 years.
True or false?
I'll have finished the assignment by lunchtime.
This time next week, I will have been living here for 10 years.
We can use the Future Perfect and Future Perfect Continuous tenses to connect two future times or actions by 'looking backwards' from a time in the future.
I'll have finished the assignment by lunchtime.
The sentence talks about an action which will continue up until a time in the future.
On Saturday, my parents will have been staying with us for two weeks.
I'll have graduated by this time next year.
We'll have been going out together for 2 years next month.
We use the Future Perfect Continuous tense to talk about actions that will continue up to a point in the future.
On Saturday, my parents will have been staying with us for two weeks.
Future Perfect Simple is used to talk about actions that will be completed before a point in the future.
We often use the continuous aspect of tenses to focus on the duration of the action.
How long will you have been studying for by the time you leave?
[k]They[/k] [k]will[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]living together[/k] [k]for 6 years[/k] [k]in June.[/k]
[k]She[/k] [k]won't[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]waiting long,[/k] [k]give her[/k] [k]a call.[/k]
[k]How long[/k] [k]will[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]working[/k] [k]here?[/k]

We form the Future Perfect Continuous tense with the following auxiliary verbs:
'will' or 'will + not' - for future
have - for perfect aspect
'been + -ing form of verb' - for continuous aspect
They will have been living together for 6 years in June.
They [k]will have been going out[/k] for two years next month.
will have gone out
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I [k]will have started[/k] a new project by then.
will have been starting
I [k]won't have been working[/k] here as long as you.
won't have working
She [k]will have left[/k] the country by then.
will have been leaving
Future Perfect Continuous - work
We [k]will have been working|will have worked[/k] together for three years this June.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Future Perfect - arrive
She [k]will have arrived[/k] at her hotel by 6 o'clock tonight.
Future Perfect Continuous - cycle
By the time they get to Paris, they [k]will have been cycling|will have cycled[/k] for over 5 hours.
Future Perfect - retire
My father [k]will have retired[/k] by this time next year.
